questions.texte: What is the main function of chlorophyll in photosynthesis?
questions.justification: As we have seen, the chemical reaction for photosynthesis requires light (absorbed by chlorophyll in the chloroplasts of leaf cells)...

questions.texte: How does carbon dioxide enter plant leaves?
questions.justification: ...carbon dioxide (which enters leaves through holes called stomata)...

questions.texte: What structures in plant roots help maximize absorption?
questions.justification: The root structure of a plant branches in a fractal pattern culminating in tiny 'hairs'... This maximizes the surface area of the roots and facilitates absorption...

questions.texte: What is the primary function of xylem?
questions.justification: ...vascular plants have stems with tissues called xylem (which transports water)...

questions.texte: What allows water to move up the xylem against gravity?
questions.justification: Water can travel up the xylem 'for free', even against the force of gravity, by way of a phenomenon called 'capillary action'.

questions.texte: What is the role of stomata in plant leaves?
questions.justification: ...carbon dioxide (which enters leaves through holes called stomata)...

questions.texte: Which plant structure is responsible for transporting sugar?
questions.justification: ...vascular plants have stems with tissues called xylem (which transports water) and phloem (which transports sugar and other organic molecules).

questions.texte: Why do non-vascular plants remain small?
questions.answerB: They do not have a vascular system for transport
questions.justification: Simple primitive plants such as mosses ('non-vascular plants') are small enough that it is not difficult to get these various resources where they need to go.

questions.texte: What property of water allows capillary action to occur?
questions.justification: Water molecules are very 'sticky' due to their polar nature...

questions.texte: Which polymer is the primary component of wood?
questions.justification: Cellulose is much 'tougher' than starch and is used primarily as a building material, making up wood and the cell walls of plant cells.

questions.texte: What is the function of mitochondria in plant cells?
questions.justification: Some of that sugar may be consumed immediately for ATP in the mitochondria.

questions.texte: What does the phloem transport?
questions.justification: ...vascular plants have stems with tissues called xylem (which transports water) and phloem (which transports sugar and other organic molecules).

questions.texte: Which structure helps plants absorb minerals from the soil?
questions.justification: The root structure of a plant branches in a fractal pattern culminating in tiny 'hairs'... This maximizes the surface area of the roots and facilitates absorption.

questions.texte: What is the main role of starch in plants?
questions.justification: Leftover sugar molecules may be chained together into a macromolecule starch to save for later.

questions.texte: How do vascular plants differ from non-vascular plants?
questions.answerA: They have a transport system for water and nutrients
questions.justification: For larger and more sophisticated 'vascular' plants, there must be a system to transport water from the roots up to the leaves.

questions.texte: What type of molecule makes up paper and allows water to climb through capillary action?
questions.justification: Paper is mostly made from a plant material called cellulose... where water could climb through capillary action, just like in the xylem.

questions.texte: What happens to excess sugar produced in photosynthesis?
questions.answerB: It is immediately burned for energy
questions.justification: Some of that sugar may be consumed immediately for ATP in the mitochondria. Leftover sugar molecules may be chained together into a macromolecule starch to save for later.

questions.texte: What is the main structural function of cellulose in plants?
questions.justification: Cellulose is much 'tougher' than starch and is used primarily as a building material, making up wood and the cell walls of plant cells.

questions.texte: What allows termites to digest cellulose?
questions.justification: ...termites (with their symbiotic gut bacteria) are capable of breaking it down into sugar as a food source.

questions.texte: Why is cellulose difficult for most animals to digest?
questions.answerB: It forms strong bonds that resist digestion
questions.justification: It is much more difficult to digest than starch for most animals -- it takes the form of 'dietary fiber' that passes right through our digestive systems.
